addressleaf.section: To the right honorable my very singular good Lord the Erle of Essex.

D
r
Birch's Memoirs Vol. [.] Page 209

page.lettertext:
fol.97r
May it please yo
r
good L. sins I sent yo
w
my
last
e 5 of this p
nt
, I have spoken w
t
Coronel Stuart
,
who hath signified unto me, as muche as I have writt
e
unto my
L. T
re
r
: wherof to avoide a newe repetiti
o
,
I have heerein sent
e transcript. And me thinkes it is
apparant, by
e general confession of
e causes of his co
m
ing,
that his errand tendes to that, w
ch
yo
r
L. knowes al-
ready. Wherein I am confirmed by some talke
at I
have had w
t
Coronel Murrey
: who is Coronel of
e Scot-
tishe regiment in these contreis: a gentleman of a chief
familie in
Scotland
well informed of
e state of his
owne contrey, and to me in particular a very good
frind: but nothing well affected to Coronel Stuart,
for w
ch
he hath bin
e freer in delivering his minde.
He assureth me
at Stuart is imploied in this message,
at his owne earnest suite, and by meanes and frind-
shippe of
e
Chancello
r
:
for
at
e
King
was unwilling,
and had no liking unto him: in so muche as he suppo-
seth (and so it is written by his frindes unto him)
that ether
e charge of his voiage is boaren by him-
self, or partly by himself, and in part by
e E
rle of
Orchney
, in whose behalf he hath to deale for
Co. Mau-
rices
sister.
He telleth me also,
at although he
knoweth not so muche by Stuart himself, yet he hath
advertism
t
by l
res
out of Scotland,
at Stuart is
willed to intreat for 1000 foote, and 500 horse,
for 6 monethes, or rather for a summe of a mony, for
the levie and pay of so many men. But as for men,
saieth he, they are not heere to be had, nor he sawe no
likelihood of obtaining
e mony: and though it should be
delivered, there were suche about
e King, as would
practise to gette it, and presently convert it to their private uses.
fol.97v
For where it is pretended,
at it shall be imploied
against
e
Erle Huntley
, and his associats, he made no ma-
ner of doubt, but if
e King were so disposed, he might
of himself subdue them out of hand. But it is
e coun-
saile, he saieth, of some about him, and especially of the
Chancello
r
,
at thinges shoul d be caried in
at kinde, to see
if her
Ma
tie
for feare of
e sequele, will yelde
e King, to
his demaundes, some better satisfaction. Howbeit he is
advetised from
e
Erle Marre
(who writeth often to
him)
at there is a plotte laid for displacing
e Chancello
r
,
w
t
e Kinges good liking. This I have
written to yo
r
L. alone, because I would not w
t
my will,
that
e name of Coronel Murrey should come in any q
e
stion,
through his speeches to me.
For all other maters
referring yo
r
L. to
e copie inclosed I take my humble
leave. From
e Hage. Fe
b
14 1594.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
